content:
Richard Hofstadter did not work directly for the government, but he did participate in some government-funded research projects and held positions that were in some way connected to government.
During the 1950s, Hofstadter was a consultant to the U.S. State Department's Committee on Cultural Presentations, which aimed to improve the image of the United States abroad by promoting American culture. He also was involved in a government-funded research project on "The American Political Mind" and in the 1960s, he was a member of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
However, most of Hofstadter's career was dedicated to teaching and researching as a professor at various universities, and publishing influential books and articles on American history and politics
